Posts.Content: Hi nannymary  It was lovely to read about someone who has come through this experience with such a positive outcome. As someone who's now embarking on the treatment part, my main worry has always been that I'd come out totally wrecked mentally and physically. I'm not deluding myself as to what could happen after reading through so many people's experiences, but your experience is also an inspiration. Good luck for the future and thanks for coming back to share this milestone with the community, hugs xx
Posts.Title: Two year milestone reached

Posts.Content: Hi Kat40 I'm on FEC only for 6 sessions, have been popping pills but tummy is getting worse. Still got the hair but absolutely shattered and have spent most of the day in bed, was hoping to see Xmas lights turned on in Edinburgh today not going to happen:( My onco unit are not keen on Picc line but will consider it on a session by session basis. Thanks K take care and keep well xx
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Hi Kate thanks for your reply, I'm female but was lucky with my pregnancies. My daughter has told me that's exactly how it feels. I'll definitely try the biscuits. I have peppermint as well as ginger sweets. Glass of wine will do nicely.:) Anyhow take care and thanks for taking time to reply, everyone is so kind. Bxx
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Hi all, had my first FEC of 6 today, and I wanted to thank you guys for advice and support re Picc line. Decided not to go for it on nurse's advice re infection and because the miracle nurse managed to get the cannula in on the second go, but we are leaving the option on the table. If I could pick your brains on how quickly side effects can manifest. I've been loaded with anti sickness pills and stuff for constipation,but was wondering about breathlessness. I've suffered from asthma in the past so I'm worried about recognising the difference. Any advice would be most welcome. Sending virtual hugs and luck to everyone xx B
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Hi K Radiotheraphy next followed by tablets.  I'm ER+. Already got all appointments set up, which is a weight off my mind. Hope you're  keeping well  xxB
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Thanks guys, that's taken a huge weight off my mind especially re the asthma. I've taken all my anti sickness meds and now keeping fingers crossed. good luck  B
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Thank crystaljuju, my stomach is pretty sore but I've always had problems with that and a few times when the nausea felt really bad.. But altogether manageable and popping pills like mad.  Hope everyone is as well as can be Take care xx
Posts.Title: 1st chemo, how soon for side effects to show

Posts.Content: Good evening guys. Hope you're all in a good place today. I had my first FEC yesterday and was given instructions about bodily fluids. Is this to be followed through the whole regime ar for a few days. With all I was being bombarded with I forgot to check.   Any advice would be great, take care and hugs to all. xx B
Posts.Title: Chemo and bodily fluids

Posts.Content: Dreamthief, you're a wonder, thanks for clearing this up. I'm in Edinburgh and got info from oncology and chemo nurse, you know how we like to be different over here Xx
Posts.Title: Chemo and bodily fluids

Posts.Content: Hello you lovely people I first joined the breast cancer group following diagnosis and op in September and got some fantastic replies to questions I had about bras.  I am now about to start chemo in about a week(although my clinic seem unable to get organised- still waiting for an exact date to start), and I want to pick your brains. I'm a rather anal person and like bullet points so bear with me. 1. PICC line. I have and have always had rubbish veins, been the bane of my life, and I'm wondering if I should just request this right at the start. 2. I am having 6 sessions of FEC(sorry a bit of levity,always feel like I'm swearing when I say that), is anyone got experience of this without T, and any ideas about dealing with side effects. 3. I want to give myself the best advantage and load up on vitamins but not sure which ones are best. With my genetic history, bones and blood issues are bound to rear their heads so any advice would be gratefully accepted. In the meantime keep fighting the good fight, you're all an inspiration to us newbies. B P.s too lazy to go through all my history, got it all written up in my profile if interested.
Posts.Title: Start of journey part 2

Posts.Content: Thanks J, you've provided some good insights. 1/2. I'm getting the cold cap but silk pillow sounds invaluable. Anything to help with sleeplessness is most welcome. My crap veins means a simple blood test takes at least two attempts and don't get me started on finding a vein for my op after fasting day before. Let's just say pin cushion is an understatement. 3. Cranberry tables are a great suggestion, I'll add it to my list.   Thanks again for the advice and good luck with everything. B
Posts.Title: Start of journey part 2

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynda, will check it out xx
Posts.Title: Megastrol

Posts.Content: Thank you all for the advice, I will definitely opt for the Picc, I have scar tissue already in one arm from the op and the stuff for the heart mri.   I liked that phrase jannie13 "FEC fec'd the veins" thanks for injecting a bit of humour into these grim proceedings;) Take care everyone  xx B
Posts.Title: Start of journey part 2

Posts.Content: Hi ladies, hope you're all keeping as well as possible. I'm back to pick your brains, just finished chemo and due to start radiotherapy but on Megastrol due to really bad hot flushes. I've now got bad cramps on my hands and feet, which I didn't have throughout chemo. Has anyone any experience of this and is there any vitamin supplements that could help. Thanks Bunmi
Posts.Title: Megastrol

Posts.Content: Good morning Peartree, I had the same procedure as yourself and had a bit of pain not as bad as you describe. It maybe you've overdone things but for peace of mind call the breast clinic, and if closed your gp or the ward you had the op. Hopefully some of the other ladies will be on to give more advice. This is a great support network  Good luckxx
Posts.Title: Stabbing, searing pain 1 week after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Thanks dawn09, I'll give them a tr
Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi all, I was diagnosed a few weeks ago and had surgery last Wednesday for removal of lump and some lymph nodes. Now home recovering. Feeling anxious one minute and calm the next and worried about results from pathology . My question is whether it's better to wear a bra to bed, I'm 34gg and finding it uncomfortable without support, but not sure if it will irritate the woun
Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi fiddlesticks    I've tried sports bra but they're very constricting, was thinking of trying a tankini with built in support. I suppose I'm worried as I had a small bleed in the lymph nodes and was not sure whether the lack of support might have been a cause. Hope you're lucky with the crop top
Posts.Title: Bras after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi fiddlesticks    I found myself in the same situation, however my daughter made the point that it's always been like that and that I'm only more aware because it's more relevant. My way of dealing is to reduce the amount of exposure, not watching much TVs at present or reading which is a passion of mine. Also picking up hobbies that you've given up due to being too busy. I think distraction is best for now. Good luc
Posts.Title: Adverts!!
